resources.string: No kernel backups yet. Why not make one?

It lowers the CPU, GPU, input boost frequency clocks, and changes some of the governor parameters to lower spikes to higher frequencies to save some precious juice during device usage
Loads the default FrancoKernel settings. It\'s a safe harbour and it\'ll yield you the best results without degrading performance.
GPU runs on it\'s maximum clock all the time, input boost duration and frequency clock are increased, and some of the governor parameters are changed for more throughput. Buttery smooth!
Your kernel doesn\'t support this feature. Ask your kernel maintainer to add support for it. Tweet me @franciscof_1990 and I can help the maintainer
New FrancoKernel is available to download!

1. Open Tasker and slide to the "Tasks" tab
2. Create a new task and give it a name. Ex.: "CPU - Games"
3. Add the "Send Intent" action which resides inside "System" group
4. Inside "Action" paste the intent you copy from below
5. Set the package name to "com.franco.kernel" (without the quotes)
6. Save the task and that's it!
Some error occurred when trying to download the kernel - can\'t pinpoint the cause - sorry!

Many studies show that exposure to bright-blue light in the evening can affect your circadian rhythms and make it harder for you to fall asleep. Night Shift automatically shifts the colors of your display to the warmer end of the color spectrum after dark. This may help you get a better night\'s sleep.
Are you sure you want to delete %s?
Night Shift isn\'t supported by your device/kernel configuration
High brightness mode isn\'t supported by your device/kernel configuration
Automatically enable when Power-saving profile is active

A set of simple suggestions & hints to improve your device\'s battery life.\nClicking the cards will expand them showing useful information.\nThe overflow menu gives you options for the tips, or direct link to those sections

Lowering the CPU clocks will greatly increase your screen on time at the expense of performance. Most of the device\'s operations aren\'t really CPU intensive, so lowering it at least 25% is enough to greatly reduce power consumption.\n\nThere are several instances in which this will show the device as \"underclocked\", even though you haven\'t applied this previously, the most notable being thermal throttling (if this is the case you won\'t be able to restore to the default clocks, your device handles it for you automatically), or your ROM/kernel has underclocked the CPU by default.

Most operations don\'t need any real GPU computation, but every time the framebuffer refreshes, the GPU core needs to come out of sleep. Some implementations even ramp up the GPU for every touch input. Reducing the maximum GPU clock can also provide some great reduction of power consumption, without adding jank

Tightly integrated with FK. This profile changes the CPU, GPU, input boost frequency and duration, and, sometimes (depending on the device), it also changes governor parameters. This profile is very aggressive and you might experience some jank here and there, but the reduction of power consumption during screen on will be immense

Disabling automatic background syncing has two sides of the same coin. For one, disabling it will certainly reduce needlessly idle wakeups (when doze isn\'t active), but then you\'ll lose some features, such as notifications for new e-mails when they arrive on your inbox, and other pieces that constantly backup/query online services. It really depends on your usage and needs

If you want to go deep into the rabbit hole, you can create custom power profiles to be applied on a per-app basis.\nSocial network apps, or Maps, news, or generally anything heavily text based without fancy elements or crazy animations will work fine on a very restrictive power profile. Since these can be applied for each app, you can leave your system defaults on all the time, and then when you open an app with a profile bound to it, let\'s say Messages, the profile will kick in and apply your settings while you\'re using it. As soon as you leave the app, the settings will go back to defaults.\nIt\'s very powerful and you can create a very unique and personal experience

With Naptime, by toggling in the \"Aggressive doze\" option, Doze will kick in right after you screen off AND it will disable your sensors so that it won\'t kick you out from Doze mode if you move around. When you turn your screen on ‚Äì everything goes back to normal. It\'s just like magic, providing you an amazing idle batter life

The display is one of the two components that use the most of the power. Even with adaptive brightness, the panel will reach high nits of light, sometimes unnecessarily. By reducing the maximum value, you\'ll save some very precious battery when you need it the most.
Root access seems to be missing

Unfortunately, nothing in this app will work without root access, so you can\'t proceed until you root your device/give the app root permissions.\n\nIf you believe this message is wrong, check your root manager app and see if you\'ve granted root permissions to this app.
Nothing to see here if Naptime isn\'t installed
Nothing to see here if Servicely isn\'t installed
Something really wrong happened, but we\'re not sure what :|
Some error happened when trying to save the profile. Try to set it up again from scratch. Sorry!
The value needs to be higher than 0 up to a maximum of 100
Automagically put all apps into App Standby after screen off. Plus other powerful feature to disable any service in any app in your device.

Wrote the current version of the auto-flasher feature (probably the only implementation in the world) and developer of the popular AnyKernel2 flashing mechanism. Without his contributions, this app\'s primary feature wouldn\'t be possible

High brightness mode allows the display\'s brightness to go above the maximum stock value.\nThis is particularly useful in direct sunlight, although it shouldn\'t be used for long periods since it increases the chance for burn-in on OLED displays and consumes way more power

This feature will automatically analyze the environment ambient light and activate High brightness mode if your surroundings are brighter than the threshold you set. It turns off if the current light value is below it
This app needs permission to write into the internal storage to function properly
Controls how Night Shift goes on or off
Detects which app is in the foreground and applies your Per-app profiles accordingly
Location permission is required to figure out the approximate sunset and sunrise times.\nIt\'s a very low power location request, only once every sunset/sunrise transition.
Pick the amount you\'re comfortable with

The supporter program is a simple & quick way for amazing users like you to take an additional step of support, recognizing the value this app provides (remember all the battery life I which helped you to save?).

Part of these proceedings are shared with others, such as the designer who made these wallpapers. Supporting me means supporting them too.

As a "thank you", you'll have this banner displayed in the Help & Support section and you'll have access to 4 exclusive and never seen before wallpapers for your device. The wallpapers are accessible by clicking the banner at the Help & Support section.
Are you sure you want to delete this?
There was an error when saving the file to internal storage

With BetterBatteryStats, you can analyse the behavior of your phone, find applications causing the phone to drain battery while it is supposed to be asleep and measure the effect of corrective actions:
¬∑ Spot drainers based on detailed information about the root cause
¬∑ measure the effect of actions to reduce drain, following a simple method
¬∑ detect changes in the awake/sleep profile and quickly find the causes (rogue apps)

In other words, BetterBatteryStats helps you achieve the best experience with your device!
Nothing to see here if BetterBatteryStats isn\'t installed

Profiles saved to /sdcard/franco.kernel_updater/governor_profiles\nIt creates a snapshot of all your governor parameters and saves it into a file that can be shared anywhere. You can also get profiles and place them on this directory so they\'ll show up here.
A profile with this name already exists

Foreground App Detection

This is used to detect which app is running in the foreground at any given time to automate tasks through Per-app profiles feature. Automation profiles are built by the users on a per-app basis.

This service only listens for typeWindowStateChanged and it can't retrieve any window content.

For transparency purposes, I'll provide the source code for this feature if asked.
Contribute to help me keep up with server costs and support more devices. You\'ll win a nice medal, 4 custom wallpapers and my forever gratitude! üôå

This tries to accurately "guess" the battery used per hour while under usage or during idle. The longer this service is left running ‚Äì the more accurate it gets.
Active idle is calculated based on your screen on time and the % lost while the display is turned on.
Idle drain is calculated based on how much % is lost any time the display is off.
Scenarios when the collected stats reset:
 ¬∑ The device reboots;
 ¬∑ It's charged to 100%;
 ¬∑ When it's unplugged from the charger.
These scenarios will help the battery data to be fresh and relevant to your current usage
Notify me if idle drain percentage goes higher than 5%
The battery monitor service detected your device is losing an average of 5% per hour. You should make sure you don\'t have any rogue apps waking your device from idle
The battery temperature unit will be updated the next time the notification refreshes
Unfortunately there\'s no automation available for your device/kernel configuration /sadface
Your device/kernel combination doesn\'t support any display control feature
Enter the file path of the tunable you want to add
Reset the stats when the device is plugged in
Set a description for this item
Change the title name of this tunable
The name can\'t be the same
The description can\'t be the same
Write a note about this tunable to help you remember what it is, what values it ranges from, etc.

This feature is for advanced users. Blocking wakelocks is solely your own responsibility and if you break anything by doing it ‚Äì then you're on your own.

That said, the only thing that can really break is an app (that really needs that wakelock to function) or some vital system functionality which needs the wakelock to do something periodically during idle.

You can check for your Wakelocks using BetterBatteryStats or any other similar app
This wakelock is already being blocked
You\'re currently not blocking any wakelocks.\n\nIf you\'re having idle drain, install BetterBatteryStats (it\'s free from XDA) and check which wakelocks are active the most and then block them here
Do you have an idea you want to see implemented - or a suggestion? You\'re in the right place!
You haven\'t yet added a description for this item
This will reset dmesg and erase all the logging messages from the kernel

Night Shift settings can and might be affected by the manufacturer\'s implementations. For example, Night Shift won\'t work on the OnePlus 6 unless you have Adaptive Display enabled. LiveDisplay by LineageOS might affect this feature too. Just be wary of this
You need to have the Battery Monitor service running to gather stats. Go to System Health -> Battery Monitor and enable it
Dialog with an auto-updating flashing log. Particularly useful for debugging

Amperage and voltage depends on the charger & cable that you\'re using. These charging values can also be affected by your usage, device heat and/or battery temperature. This feature simply reads the values from the kernel, but they might not a 100% accurate representation of the real electricity current, so take these as an estimation.\nIf for some reason these stats don\'t show up, then it\'s likely your device has different paths. Contact me and we\'ll figure it out together
You can\'t put offline CPU0 because it\'s essential and vital for device\'s functions

Turning off cores is a quick and dirty way to save some power. Be wary, the device will likely suffer some performance loss exponentially to the amount of cores going offline.\nAlso some chips will have restrictions. For example, on big.Little devices the big cluster will always need one core online
This tip has already been applied
This tip has been set on boot
Add your backup note below (like if you need to add some information about this particular kernel backup)
You can\'t add an empty note
Are you sure you want to restore this kernel backup? The kernel will be available after a reboot
Working on disabling ZRAM, it can take up to 1‚Äì2 minutes to complete‚Ä¶
Working on changing ZRAM disksize. It can take up to 1‚Äì2 minutes depending on the size you\'ve set‚Ä¶
There isn\'t any string with that search term
Welcome to the new Per-app profiles experience

Below you\'ll choose between two different ways to create and manage your app profiles. \nIf this is the first time you\'re using this feature, I strongly recommend you trying the \"Simple mode\" first.\nYou can change your choice later at Settings if you wish.
You\'ll be guided through all the steps with descriptions along the way
All the options will be displayed right away with no descriptions. This mode assumes you\'ve made profiles before and are used to this feature
To start things off, we need to enable the background service that\'ll be responsible to apply your profile when apps are open and you\'re interacting with them

Now it\'s time to choose to which app you want to apply your profile. When this app goes into the foreground, the profile is applied automagically. When it goes to the background, your previous device settings will be re-applied\n\nDon\'t worry, you\'ll be able to change this afterwards if you change your mind üôÇ
Choose an app to apply the profile

One of the most important settings, and likely the option that\'ll save you the most battery. Each device has a minimum and a maximum CPU frequency, and, depending on the system load, the freq will scale up and down. Depending on the app you\'ve chosen, it may be wise to lower the max frequency in order to save battery.\n\nFor example, if you\'re using Google Maps, your device is using a lot of power with active GPS, display and all the sensors, so by lowering max freq you will not run out of juice so fast.
Set max freq low power CPUs
Set max freq for high perf CPUs
Change the max freq for your CPUs

Same as with the CPU max frequency, the GPU works exactly the same way. If what you\'re doing something that isn\'t graphically intensive, there\'s no real need to allow the GPU to scale so high and use more power.\n\nGeneral rule of thumb: you can set a lower than max GPU freq unless you\'re applying this profile to a game ‚ú®

You'll likely don't need a WiFi or GPS when reading a book through the Kindle app, or you want to use the phone in a certain orientation specifically for that one app.

All the settings that you'll choose below are applied when the app you've selected is opened.

To proceed and save this profile, you must choose settings for WiFi, GPS, display orientation and Android battery saver and they'll appear below sequentially. If you don't want to change any of these settings, just leave them at "Unchanged" and you're good to go üëç
Stop the setup wizard and return to the initial menu

Thank you so much for becoming a FK Kernel Manager Supporter!

As a constant reminder of your generous support, you'll proudly display a Supporter badge banner in the Help menu! And more, clicking the banner gives you access to the amazing custom wallpapers.

Thanks again!

Cannot fetch a last location. Open Google Maps to force the device into locking into the GPS for you.
Reset the stats when the battery reaches a certain percentage
Cluster #1 CPU reset frequency after a boost
Cluster #2 CPU reset frequency after a boost
A switch to enable or disable klapse
The hour at which klapse should start scaling the RGB values from daytime to target (see next points)
The hour by which klapse should scale back the RGB values from target to daytime (see next points)
The RGB set that must be used for all the time outside of start and stop hour range
The RGB set that must be scaled towards for all the time inside of start and stop hour range

Controls how soon the RGB reaches from daytime to target inside of start and stop hour range. Once target is reached, it remains constant till 30 minutes before stop hour, where target RGB scales back to daytime RGB

From the name itself, this value has the ability to bend perception and make your display appear as if it is at a lesser brightness level than it actually is at. It works by reducing the RGB values by the same factor
[2, 10] (10 means accurate brightness, 5 means 50% of current brightness, etc)
A switch that allows you to automatically set the brightness factor in a set time range
The hour at which brightness_factor should be applied. Depends on brightness_factor_auto = 1.
The hour at which brightness_factor should be reverted to 10. Depends on brightness_factor_auto = 1.
The brightness range within which klapse should scale from daytime to target_rgb. Depends on enable_klapse = 2.
[2, 1023] (first value is lower and second is upper, lower being smaller than upper must be true)
The amount of milliseconds after which klapse_pulse is called. A more developer-targeted tunable. Depends on enable_klapse = 1 OR brightness_factor_auto = 1
The number of minutes before klapse_stop_hour when RGB should start going back to daytime_rgb. Depends on enable_klapse = 1.
A script with this name already exists
Shell scripts are stored in /sdcard/franco.kernel_updater/scripts/\nImported scripts are copied to that location as well
